table-wrap.anchoringText: Some additional classification criteria were incorporated into the database and arranged in a conceptual well classification matrix (Table 1). The main discriminator was the type of fluid produced by the well (composition), complemented by the the landing zone (zonation) and the location relative to the slope break of clinoforms.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Classification criteria for Vaca Muerta horizontal wells.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Classification criteria for Vaca Muerta horizontal wells.

tr.th: Location Relative to clinoform slope breaks

tr.td:

• Volatile oil
• Gas condensate

• Dry gas

U pper prograding

• 1b (between T2 and T3 slope breaks)
• 2a (between T3 and T4 slope breaks)
• 2b (between T4 and T5 slope breaks)
• 3a (between T5 and B1 slope breaks)
• 3b (between B1 and B2 slope breaks)
• 4a (between B2 and B3 slope breaks)
• 4b (between B3 and B4 slope breaks)
• 5 (between B4 and V2 slope breaks)
• 6a (between V2 and V3 slope breaks)

table-wrap.anchoringText: Only wells producing black oil and located in zones 2a and 2b are able to be model type curves for it. Wells producing dry gas located in zones 4a and 4b also produce a good enough sample, but most of its monthly production data series are still too short to carry out the procedure with statistical significance (Table 2).
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Well sample count when combining fluid type and location discrimination criteria.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well sample count when combining fluid type and location discrimination criteria.

td.b: Wet oil, gas condensate, wet gas
